message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Sharing of misinformation is habitual, not just lazy or biased
Paper Abstract: Why do people share misinformation on social media? In this research ( N = 2,476), we show that the structure of online sharing built into social platforms is more important than individual deficits in critical reasoning and partisan bias—commonly cited drivers of misinformation. Due to the reward-based learning systems on social media, users form habits of sharing information that attracts others' attention. Once habits form, information sharing is automatically activated by cues on the platform without users considering response outcomes such as spreading misinformation. As a result of user habits, 30 to 40% of the false news shared in our research was due to the 15% most habitual news sharers. Suggesting that sharing of false news is part of a broader response pattern established by social media platforms, habitual users also shared information that challenged their own political beliefs. Finally, we show that sharing of false news is not an inevitable consequence of user habits: Social media sites could be restructured to build habits to share accurate information.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Habit formation"

Links: [{"title":"Habit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Habit"},{"title":"Dynamic unobserved effects model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_unobserved_effects_model"},{"title":"Talk:Child vehicular heat stroke deaths - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Forgotten_baby_syndrome"},{"title":"Crystal habit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crystal_habit"},{"title":"Botryoidal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Botryoidal"}]

Here's what I found about habit formation:

## Definition and Overview

Habit formation is the process by which a behavior, through regular repetition, becomes automatic or habitual.(no content)Habitual behavior often goes unnoticed by persons exhibiting it, because a person does not need to engage in self-analysis when undertaking routine tasks. In fact, approximately 43% of daily behaviors are performed out of habit.

## How Long Does It Take?

The average time for participants to reach the asymptote of automaticity was 66 days with a range of 18–254 days.(no content)This process of habit formation can be slow.

## The Four Components

There are four main components to habit formation: the context cue, craving, behavioral repetition, and the reward. The context cue can be a prior action, time of day, location, or anything that triggers the habitual behavior. The cue leads to a craving or desire. The craving is the motivational force behind the habit.

## Why Habits Are Difficult to Change

Old habits are hard to break and new habits are hard to form because the behavioural patterns that humans repeat become imprinted in neural pathways, but it is possible to form new habits through repetition.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Misinformation"

Links: [{"title":"Misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation"},{"title":"COVID-19 misinformation by governments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation_by_governments"},{"title":"COVID-19 misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation"},{"title":"Misinformation in the Gaza war - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation_in_the_Gaza_war"},{"title":"Vaccine misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaccine_misinformation"},{"title":"COVID-19 misinformation by China - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation_by_China"},{"title":"5G misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/5G_misinformation"},{"title":"Misinformation about violence by transgender people - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation_about_violence_by_transgender_people"},{"title":"Misinformation about the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation_about_the_2024_Atlantic_hurricane_season"},{"title":"Seed oil misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seed_oil_misinformation"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about misinformation:

## Definition

Misinformation is incorrect or misleading information. More specifically, misinformation is information that was originally thought to be true but was later discovered not to be true, and often applies to emerging situations in which there is a lack of verifiable information or changing scientific understanding.

## Key Characteristics

Here are the search results for "Social Media":

## Overview

Social media platforms allow individuals, communities, businesses, and organizations to share, co-create, discuss, participate in, and modify user-generated or self-curated content.(no content)Social media is used to share memories, form friendships, build communities and learn.

## Definition

Social media marketing is the use of social media platforms and websites to promote a product or service.(no content)The term social media was first used in 2004 and is often used to describe social networking services.

## Popular Platforms

Popular social media platforms with over 100 million registered users include Twitter, Facebook, WeChat, ShareChat, Instagram, Pinterest, QZone, Weibo, VK, Tumblr, Baidu Tieba, Threads and LinkedIn.

## Usage Statistics

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media some 59% of the global population.

## Comparison to Traditional Media

Social media outlets operate in a dialogic transmission system (many sources to many receivers) while traditional media operate under a monologic transmission model (one source to many receivers).

## Impact and Concerns

Social media has been criticized for a range of negative impacts on children and teenagers, including exposure to inappropriate content, exploitation by adults, sleep problems, attention problems, feelings of exclusion, and various mental health maladies.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Confirmation bias"

Links: [{"title":"Confirmation bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confirmation_bias"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Confirmation bias bias confirmed - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Confirmation_bias_bias_confirmed"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Peer review/Confirmation bias/archive1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Peer_review/Confirmation_bias/archive1"},{"title":"List of cognitive biases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cognitive_biases"},{"title":"Selection bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selection_bias"},{"title":"Cognitive bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_bias"},{"title":"Belief bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belief_bias"},{"title":"Selective perception - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selective_perception"}]

Here's comprehensive information about confirmation bias based on the search results:

## Definition

Confirmation bias is the tendency to search for, interpret, favor and recall information in a way that confirms or supports one's prior beliefs or values.

## How It Works

People tend to test hypotheses in a one-sided way, by searching for evidence consistent with their current hypothesis. Rather than searching through all the relevant evidence, they phrase questions to receive an affirmative answer that supports their theory. They look for the consequences that they would expect if their hypothesis were true, rather than what would happen if it were false.

## Historical Background

A series of psychological experiments in the 1960s suggested that people are biased toward confirming their existing beliefs.(no content)Confirmation bias was refined by English psychologist Peter Wason, as "a preference for information that is consistent with a hypothesis rather than information which opposes it."

## Why It Happens

Explanations for the observed biases include wishful thinking and the limited human capacity to process information.

## Real-World Consequences

Flawed decisions due to confirmation bias have been found in a wide range of political, organizational, financial and scientific contexts. Examples include a police detective who may identify a suspect early in an investigation, but then may only seek confirming rather than disconfirming evidence, and in social media, confirmation bias is amplified by the use of filter bubbles and "algorithmic editing", which display to individuals only information they are likely to agree with, while excluding opposing views.

Web search results for query: "Reward learning"

Links: [{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Reward system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reward_system"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning from human feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning_from_human_feedback"},{"title":"Kate Wassum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kate_Wassum"},{"title":"Reward hacking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reward_hacking"},{"title":"Q-learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning"},{"title":"State–action–reward–state–action - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State-action-reward-state-action"},{"title":"Reinforcement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement"},{"title":"Brain stimulation reward - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brain_stimulation_reward"},{"title":"Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of reward learning:

## Overview

Reward learning is a concept that spans both machine learning and neuroscience:

### Machine Learning Context

In machine learning, reward learning is most closely associated with reinforcement learning (RL), which is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.

Key aspects of reward learning in this domain include:

- **Core Mechanism**: Executing an action in a specific state provides the agent with a reward (a numerical score). The goal of the agent is to maximize its totalreward.

- **Decision Making**: To learn to maximize rewards from interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

- **Advanced Applications**: Reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) is a technique to align an intelligent agent with human preferences. It involves training a reward model to represent preferences, which can then be used to train other models through reinforcement learning.

### Neuroscience Context

The reward system (the mesocorticolimbic circuit) is a group of neural structures responsible for incentive salience (i.e., "wanting"; desire or craving for a reward and motivation), associative learning (primarily positive reinforcement and classical conditioning), and positively-valenced emotions.

Reward learning involves understanding how organisms learn to associate stimuli with rewards and modify their behavior accordingly through their brain's reward circuits.

## Overview

Reward learning is a concept that spans both machine learning and neuroscience:

### Machine Learning Context

In machine learning, reward learning is most closely associated with reinforcement learning (RL), which is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.

Key aspects of reward learning in this domain include:

- **Core Mechanism**: Executing an action in a specific state provides the agent with a reward (a numerical score). The goal of the agent is to maximize its totalreward.

- **Decision Making**: To learn to maximize rewards from interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

- **Advanced Applications**: Reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) is a technique to align an intelligent agent with human preferences. It involves training a reward model to represent preferences, which can then be used to train other models through reinforcement learning.

### Neuroscience Context

The reward system (the mesocorticolimbic circuit) is a group of neural structures responsible for incentive salience (i.e., "wanting"; desire or craving for a reward and motivation), associative learning (primarily positive reinforcement and classical conditioning), and positively-valenced emotions.

message_text:
## Summary

I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Sharing of misinformation is habitual, not just lazy or biased" and generated the triples output. Here's what was accomplished:

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (the paper proposes novel findings about habit formation in misinformation sharing)

**Extracted Triples (5 total):**

1. **Misinformation** (concept) - uses relation
   - The paper investigates how misinformation is shared on social media platforms

2. **Social media** (tool) - uses relation
   - Primary context where habitual sharing behaviors develop and false news spreads

3. **Habit** (concept) - proposes relation
   - Novel proposal that information sharing is driven by habits formed through reward-based learning

4. **Reinforcement learning** (concept) - uses relation
   - Explains how social media platforms train users to share through engagement metrics

5. **Confirmation bias** (concept) - uses relation
   - Paper challenges this bias as a primary driver, showing habits matter more

**Validation Result:** ✅ PASSED
- All Wikipedia URLs verified
- All validation requirements met (at least 1 "uses" triple, contribution paper has "proposes" triples)

The triples_output.json file has been successfully updated and validated.
